algorithms.imageProcessing

Class CannyEdgeFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.imageProcessing.CannyEdgeFilter

  • public class CannyEdgeFilter
extends java.lang.Object
    The CannyEdge filter is an algorithm to operate on an image to replace objects with their edges. The implementation here is slightly different/ The images are first normalized by histogram equalization. Then the x and y gradients of the image are found. The combination of the x and y gradients are used as the input for the rest of the algorithm. "hysteresis thresholding" is performed as a 2 layer filter to remove the lowest intensity pixels in an image and then to remove pixels not connected to the highest intensity pixels. A line thinner is used here instead of "non-maximal" suppression to thin the edges. An additional stage of line thinning is applied to edges that are at a 45 degree angle as suggested by the ECSS paper.
    Author:
    nichole

      • doNotPerformHistogramEqualization

        public void doNotPerformHistogramEqualization()
        apply histogram normalization before processing. For some images, this will increase the contrast of fainter features.

      • setAdditionalImageBlur

        public void setAdditionalImageBlur(float sigma)
        used to apply an additional round of gaussian blurring to the image input before the 2-layer filter is applied. Expected use is by an invoker that has learned that it needs a lower resolution image to make fewer corners, for example.
        Parameters:
        sigma -

      • useLineDrawingMode

        public void useLineDrawingMode()
        Line Drawing Mode uses the difference of Gaussians instead of 1st deriv Gaussian to try to keep the lines thinner from the start. (1) convolve the image with a Gaussian sigma=1 kernel as 1D operations in X and Y separately. (2) convolve those with a Gaussian sigma=1 kernel again and that results in an image convolved in total by sqrt(2). (3) The X gradient is the second convolution - the first, so that is effectively a factor of sqrt(2) = 1.414 which is close to the recommended 1.6 to mimic a Laplacian filter. The same is done for Y.

      • reApply2LayerFilter

        public void reApply2LayerFilter(GreyscaleImage gradientXYImage,
                                GreyscaleImage gradientThetaImage,
                                HistogramHolder imgHistogram)
        after applyFilter has already been used, this method can be used after changing the settings such as overrideLowThreshold to re-process the image products with the changed settings. Note that gradientXYImage is modified in the process, but gradientThetaImage and imgHistogram are not.
        Parameters:
        gradientXYImage -
        gradientThetaImage -
        imgHistogram -
